Introduction to International Financial Management

Chapter 1 - FIN542 | Semester Oct 2023 - Feb 2024

Explore the world of multinational financial management, theories of international business, and the global strategies that drive modern corporations.

Start Learning Take Quiz

Multinational Financial Management

Multinational Financial Management is concerned with how to optimize the various corporate decisions across national boundaries.

Key Focus Areas:

  • Working Capital Management
  • Investment Decisions
  • Financing Strategies
  • Dividend Policy

Key Principles:

  • Money has no boundary
  • Financial markets have become highly integrated
  • Consumption and production have become globally interconnected
Global financial operations across borders

YouTube video: Introduction to Multinational Financial Management

Real World Example

Apple Inc.'s Global Financial Strategy

Apple Inc. manages a complex multinational financial operation with subsidiaries in Ireland, Singapore, and various other countries. The company optimizes its:

  • Working Capital: Through just-in-time manufacturing
  • Investments: Strategic acquisition of technology companies globally
  • Financing: Issuing bonds in different markets to take advantage of lower interest rates
  • Dividend Policy: Balancing dividend payments with growth investments

This strategic approach has helped Apple maintain its position as one of the world's most valuable companies.

The Rise of Multinational Corporations

What is a Multinational Corporation?

An MNC is defined as a company that has operating subsidiaries located in foreign countries. The parent company is usually located in the home country while several subsidiaries are in foreign countries.

According to Foley et al. (2021), MNCs are defined as business entities with one or more foreign affiliates in which the parent company holds at least a 10% ownership stake.

Objectives of MNCs

The primary objective of MNCs is to make decisions that are best for the corporation as a whole.

MNCs emphasize group performance rather than individual parts.

This holistic approach allows MNCs to optimize resources across countries, taking advantage of different market conditions, tax systems, and business environments.

Types of Multinational Corporations

Raw Materials Seekers

MNCs that aim to exploit raw materials found in foreign countries, either for export or further processing.

Example: Shell, Rio Tinto, Exxon Mobil

Market Seekers

Companies that venture overseas to produce and sell in foreign markets to meet local demand or export to markets beyond their home.

Example: McDonald's, Tesco, Nestl√©

Cost Production Efficiency Seekers

Firms that seek to produce in countries with little competition or lower costs of production factors.

Example: Nike, Apple, Samsung

Knowledge Seekers

Companies that expand abroad to gain knowledge and experience not available in their home market.

Example: Tech companies, Research partnerships

Keeping Domestic Customers

Firms that venture into foreign markets by following their primary customers who go abroad.

Example: Banking services, Component suppliers

Exploiting Financial Market Imperfections

Companies that conduct foreign direct investment to reduce risks through international diversification.

Example: Investment banks, Insurance companies

YouTube video: The Rise and Impact of Multinational Corporations

Real World Example

Unilever: A Mix of MNC Types

Unilever represents a multinational corporation that combines multiple MNC types:

  • Market Seeker: Adapts products to local tastes (e.g., different Lipton tea formulations for different markets)
  • Raw Materials Seeker: Sources palm oil and other ingredients from countries like Indonesia and Malaysia
  • Cost Efficiency Seeker: Manufactures in lower-cost regions while maintaining quality standards
  • Knowledge Seeker: Establishes R&D centers globally to tap into different innovation ecosystems

This multi-faceted approach has allowed Unilever to become one of the world's largest consumer goods companies, with products sold in over 190 countries.

Theories of International Business

Theory of Comparative Advantage

Each country should specialize in the production and export of goods it can produce with relative efficiency.

  • Specialize in goods with highest relative efficiency
  • Import goods that cannot be produced efficiently

Example:

Japan exports electronics and imports agricultural products, while Brazil exports agricultural goods and imports electronics.

Theory of Imperfect Markets

Countries differ with respect to the resources available for the production of goods.

  • Firms capitalize on foreign country's resources
  • Exploitation of market imperfections and differences

Example:

US tech companies setting up R&D centers in India to leverage lower labor costs and strong technical education.

Theory of Product Life Cycle

As time passes, products may reach maturity or declining stages in the home country.

  • Firms produce in foreign markets to reduce costs
  • Gain new customers in emerging markets

Example:

Television manufacturers moving production from Japan to Malaysia, then to Vietnam as products mature.

Product Life Cycle in International Business

Introduction

Production begins in home country. Product is innovative and unstandardized. Companies focus on domestic market.

Growth

Increasing foreign demand leads to exports. Competitors emerge in advanced nations. Companies begin producing in foreign developed markets.

Maturity

Product becomes standardized. Companies shift production to developing countries with lower costs. Home country may become net importer.

Decline

Production concentrated in developing countries. Developed nations import. Companies focus on cost minimization or product innovation.

YouTube video: Theories of International Business Explained

Real World Example

Toyota's Global Strategy

Toyota exemplifies the application of international business theories:

  • Comparative Advantage: Leverages Japan's engineering expertise while outsourcing component production
  • Imperfect Markets: Establishes manufacturing in countries with lower labor costs and favorable regulations
  • Product Life Cycle: Introduced the Prius first in Japan, then in developed markets like the US, and later adapted models for emerging markets

Toyota's strategy has evolved from exporting Japanese-made vehicles to a sophisticated global production network with regional manufacturing hubs tailored to local market conditions.

Process of Overseas Expansion

Expansion Stages

Companies typically follow a progression of international involvement, starting with lower-risk approaches and gradually increasing their commitment to foreign markets.

Exporting

A conservative approach to penetrate foreign markets, especially when demand abroad is uncertain. Requires minimal capital and offers low start-up costs. The risk is low and profits can be immediate. Allows companies to learn about foreign market conditions before further expansion.

Example:

A small electronics manufacturer in Taiwan exporting components to the US market without establishing a physical presence there.

Risks of International Business

Foreign Exchange Risk

Due to fluctuations in currency exchange rates

Political Risk

Related to political stability, government changes, riots

Economic Risk

Interest rates, inflation, currency controls

Geographical Risk

Location factors, climate, natural disasters

Legal Risk

Different laws and regulations in host countries

Socio-cultural Risk

Religion, ethnic differences, customs, beliefs

Benefits of International Business

Variety and Quality of Goods

Access to a wider variety of products and services from around the world

Lower Production Costs

Economies of scale and access to cheaper resources

Technology Transfer

Sharing of technological knowledge and know-how across borders

Economic Growth

Creation of jobs, increased trade, and economic development

Diplomatic Relationships

Improved international relations and cooperation between countries

Multinational Financial Management Goals

Primary Goal

To maximize the shareholders' wealth as measured by the share price.

This goal remains consistent with domestic financial management, but requires considering additional factors such as currency fluctuations, political risks, and different legal systems.

Centralized Financial Management

Parent company managers control the financial decisions of foreign subsidiaries

Decentralized Financial Management

Subsidiary managers make financial decisions pertaining to their subsidiaries

YouTube video: The International Expansion Process

Real World Example

Starbucks: A Global Expansion Journey

Starbucks demonstrates a methodical approach to international expansion:

  • Initial Exporting: Began by selling coffee beans to international markets
  • Joint Ventures: Partnered with local companies in Japan (Sazaby Inc.) and the UK (Seattle Coffee Company)
  • Licensing: Used in some markets like airports and hotels
  • Wholly-Owned Subsidiaries: Eventually established company-owned stores in key markets
  • Franchising: Expanded through franchising in markets like South Korea and the Philippines

Starbucks adapted its entry strategies based on local market conditions, cultural preferences, and regulatory environments. This flexible approach allowed the company to grow from a single store in Seattle to over 33,000 stores in 80+ countries.
